children.subject:
The student answer of @11570 quotes a response from Sahai in the CS 70 Piazza, which may alleviate some concerns.

I'm in a similar situation to you (P/NP-ing 3 upper-divs) and I don't think admissions committees will devalue your application because of it. In the context of zoom learning and take-home exams, it's hard to keep the same standard of teaching compared to previous semesters, and I think admissions will take that into account. Even in the case that you don't P/NP and do worse in those classes, it would be easy to address on an "extenuating circumstances" portion of the application.

history.content: I think if you have the resources to commit, having a letter grade will be better. But otherwise, take it P/NP and every grad school will understand that Spring 2020 was a weird semester for everyone. Plus, you have grades from your other semesters to back you up anyways.

I am a transfer eecs student and this is my last semester here at Berkeley. Given the transfer curriculum, we generally are only able to take our five upper-division requirements on our second year. So for me I am taking 3 out of the 5 upper-division requirements right now and given the current situation how bad would it seem to have most of my upper-division requirements all become P/NP rather than letter grade? I am considering on applying to a masters program in the near future and my main concern is how my bad my application would be affected.
history.subject: Grading Option
